taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013
IUCN Red List (Species Assessed for Global Conservation)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Found in rocky habitats.  Feeds from the biocover by nibbling and picking on the algae (Ref. 5595).  Aquarium keeping:  aggressive towards conspecifics; many females for one male; minimum aquarium size 100 cm (Ref. 51539).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations
dataObjects.title: Known prey organisms
dataObjects.description:
Pseudotropheus auratus (Pseudotropheus elongatus, P. tropheops, P. minutus, P. auratus, P. fuscus, Labeotropheus fuelleborni, L. trewavasae) preys on:
Aufwuchs

Based on studies in:
Malawi, Lake Nyasa (Lake or pond)

This list may not be complete but is based on published studies.
dataObjects.references: G. Fryer, The trophic interrelationships and ecology of some littoral communities of Lake Nyasa, Proc. London Zool. Soc. 132:153-281, from p. 217 (1959).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObjects.description: Cryptobia Infestation. Parasitic infestations (protozoa, worms, etc.)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObjects.description: Lays up to 40 eggs. Female takes brood into her mouth and takes care of the young.

dataObjects.title: File:Melanochromis auratus.jpg

dataObjects.title: File:The Biggest Fish In The Tank 2086574261.jpg
dataObjects.description: Melanochromis auratus, adult male  As soon as I try to shoot the fishes in our tank, their chieftain comes to check out my camera. ;-)
